item.title: La Cabra
item.description:
<p>Masicka delivers lyrical precision and confidence on <em>La Cabra</em> – Spanish for <em>The Goat</em> – reinforcing his claim to greatness with razor-sharp wordplay and heavyweight production. Plus Popcaan's new drop <em>Proving</em>, a tough street tune laced with his trademark flow and attitude, showing the Unruly Boss in commanding form.</p>
<p>We also pay tribute to Alton Ellis on the anniversary of his passing – the soulful pioneer who helped shape rocksteady, and the very language of Jamaican music. His influence continues to echo through every generation.</p>

item.title: Go Deh Yaka
item.description: <p>This week on Riddim Yard: 80s funk-reggae from Brooklyn group <strong>Monyaka</strong> and their album <em>Reggaenomics</em> - plus lesser-known gems from <strong>Dennis Brown</strong>, produced by <strong>Bunny Gemini</strong> on the <strong>Record Factory</strong> label. Also 90s dancehall from <strong>Charlie Chaplin</strong> and <strong>Josey Wales</strong> (<em>King of the Dancehall</em>), and roots from <strong>Delroy Williams</strong> with his 1982 album <em>I Stand Black</em> - produced by <strong>Augustus Pablo</strong> for the <strong>Message</strong> label.</p>
item.author: Rick Howe

item.title: RIP Vivian Jones
item.description:
<p>In the wake of Hurricane Melissa that devistated Jamaica this week, we pay tribute to Jamaican born British reggae singer Vivian Jones who passed away in London this week aged 68. Better known for his contribution to the creation of the Lovers Rock genre, but Riddim Yard focusses on his Roots gems from the 80s to today.</p>
<p>Plus late 80s dancehall on the Skengdon label with singers like Gregory Isaacs and Junior Delgado, and brand new dancehall from Jahvillani.</p>

item.title: RIP Jimmy Cliff
item.description:
<p>A tribute to reggae legend and Jamaican cultural icon <strong>Jimmy Cliff</strong>, who passed away this week at the age of 81. A master songwriter with nuff crossover hits, but Riddim Yard shines a light on his early ska recordings and some of the lesser-known gems that shaped his foundation years. We also revisit the soundtrack to <em>The Harder They Come</em> - the 1972 film that introduced global audiences to Kingston’s struggles, spirit and music culture, and helped cement Cliff as one of reggae’s defining voices.</p>
<p>There’s brand new up-to-the-times dancehall from <strong>Vybz Kartel</strong>, the Wurl Boss himself, with his fiery new single <em>Guapi</em>.</p>
item.author: Rick Howe

item.title: Special guest Stranger Cole
item.description:
<p>Ahead of his Australian tour, ska pioneer <strong>Stranger Cole</strong> returns to the Riddim Yard studio eight years on from his 2017 visit. He joins us alongside <strong>Jane Hilson</strong> of <strong>Miss SkaTonic</strong>, ahead of their show supporting Stranger Cole, backed by <strong>The Ska Vendors</strong>, at the Brunswick Ballroom on Saturday 13 December.</p>
<p>Plus, it's war season in dancehall. <strong>Masicka has Tommy Lee Sparta in his sights</strong>, firing off two new savage diss tracks. This one could get ugly...</p>
